title: Ticket #1531: Manual section on the dedicated scheduler is really misleading
description:
In Section 3.13.10 of the Manual, "Condor's Dedicated Scheduling", the big picture/intro is really misleading. The only reason one needs to bother setting up a dedicated scheduler is to support the execution of parallel universe jobs. Instead of simply stating this, the manual has a bunch of text implying that you need to setup a dedicated scheduler if you have dedicated resources (as opposed to opportunistic resources). That's nuts, if you have dedicated resources, just set START=True, SUSPEND=FALSE, and PREEMPT=FALSE on your cluster machines, and you're done. Seems like this book chapter does a better job of explaining all this, maybe the Manual should lift some text/examples from it.

Behold the misleading Manual text:

  Applications that require multiple resources, yet must not be preempted, are handled gracefully by Condor. Condor combines opportunistic scheduling and dedicated scheduling within a single system. Opportunistic scheduling involves placing a job on a non-dedicated resource under the assumption that the resource may not be available for the entire duration of the job. Dedicated scheduling assumes the constant availability of resources; it is assumed that the job will run to completion, without interruption. To support applications needing dedicated resources, an administrator configures resources to be dedicated. These resources are controlled by a dedicated scheduler, a single machine within the pool that runs a condor_schedd daemon.
